S3.T1.caption: Table 1. Overview of constants and variables
S3.T1.table:
System-related constants
C𝐶C set of clients
P𝑃P set of power domains
Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p} set of clients in power domain p𝑝p
mcsubscript𝑚𝑐m_{c} maximum capacity of client c𝑐c (batches/timestep)
δcsubscript𝛿𝑐\delta_{c} energy efficiency of client c𝑐c (energy/batch)
User-defined constants
n𝑛n number of selected clients per round
dmaxsuperscript𝑑maxd^{\text{max}} maximum round duration in multiples of t𝑡t
mcmin;mcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑐minsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑐maxm_{c}^{\text{min}};m_{c}^{\text{max}} minimum/maximum number of batches client c𝑐c must participate per round
Input variables (updated each round)
mc,tspare∈[0,mc]superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑐𝑡spare0subscript𝑚𝑐m_{c,t}^{\text{spare}}\in[0,m_{c}] spare capacity forecast for client c𝑐c at time t𝑡t
rp,tsubscript𝑟𝑝𝑡r_{p,t} excess energy forecast for power domain p𝑝p at time t𝑡t
σcsubscript𝜎𝑐\sigma_{c} fairness weighting of client c𝑐c
Optimization variables (determined each round)
d𝑑d expected round duration
bc∈{0,1}subscript𝑏𝑐01b_{c}\in\{0,1\} whether or not client c𝑐c is selected
mc,texp∈[0,mc,tspare]superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑐𝑡exp0superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑐𝑡sparem_{c,t}^{\text{exp}}\in[0,m_{c,t}^{\text{spare}}] expected number of batches client c𝑐c will compute at time t𝑡t considering energy and capacity constraints
references:
We define C𝐶C as the set of clients distributed over a disjunct set of power domains P𝑃P.
Clients are characterized by their energy efficiency δcsubscript𝛿𝑐\delta_{c} and maximum computing capacity mcsubscript𝑚𝑐m_{c}.
For simplicity, we do not consider other resources like memory in this work, but they can be integrated the same way as mcsubscript𝑚𝑐m_{c}.
We divide time into slots of duration t𝑡t, so an estimated training round duration d𝑑d is always a multiple of t𝑡t.
The duration of t𝑡t depends on the problem setting but is usually in the order of one minute.
We define the training of a mini-batch, from now on called batch, as an atomic operation to be performed within these time slots.
Table 1 provides an overview of all introduced variables and constants.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2. Max energy consumption and training performance of the three types of clients.
S5.T2.table:
client max performance (samples per minute)
type energy DenseNet-121 EfficientNet-B1 LSTM KWT-1
small 70 W 110 118 276 87
mid 300 W 384 411 956 303
large 700 W 742 795 1856 586
references:
Clients.  
We model heterogeneity among clients by randomly assigning them to one of three types (small, medium, large) that are roughly based on the performance333https://developer.nvidia.com/deep-learning-performance-training-inference and energy usage characteristics of T4, V100, and A100 GPUs, respectively.
However, we downscaled their actual compute capabilities (samples per minute), as shown in Table 2.
We use 100 randomly selected machines from the Alibaba GPU cluster trace dataset (Weng et al., 2022) to model client load (gpu_wrk_util) and load forecasts (gpu_plan).

The number of samples computed per timestep was obtained through benchmarking runs and is stated in Table 2.
All simulations use a timestep t=1𝑡1t=1  min and a max round duration dmax=60superscript𝑑max60d^{\text{max}}=60 min.
We select n=10𝑛10n=10 clients each round which have to compute 1 to 5 local epochs, so mm​i​nsuperscript𝑚𝑚𝑖𝑛m^{min} and mm​a​xsuperscript𝑚𝑚𝑎𝑥m^{max} depend on the locally available number of samples.
Clients locally train on minibatches of size 10.
We ran each experiment five times over the course of seven simulated days and report mean values.

Time-to-accuracy and energy-to-accuracy.  
To further demonstrate how FedZero improves FL under energy and capacity constraints, we define the top accuracy of the Random baseline as our target accuracy for a specific experiment.
Table 3 reports the time and energy required for FedZero and the baselines to reach this target accuracy.
The table only contains the best-performing baselines; a full table with all results can be found in Appendix A.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4. CIFAR-100 performance on the global scenario under imbalanced conditions (Berlin has unlimited resources).
S5.T4.table:
Best accuracy Time-to-acc. Energy-to-acc.
Random 64.6 % 6.7 d 95.7 kWh
Oort 65.6 % 4.5 d 189.4 kWh
FedZero 66.9 % 3.5 d 83.4 kWh
references:
Table 4 displays the training performance of the three approaches in the scenario where Berlin has unlimited resources.
We observe that Random used 19 % more energy and Oort even twice the energy in the imbalanced scenario (Figure LABEL:fig:eval_fairness-b) for reaching a comparable accuracy as in the base scenario (Figure LABEL:fig:eval_fairness-a).
FedZero used only 4 % more energy and reduced its time-to-accuracy.
